crypto.name: Abramov
crypto.desc:
Abramov’s complex numbers are so precise, even MATLAB would demand a PostDoc to verify them!

Note: In the output.txt please change the z ** s to z ** t!

crypto.name: Empties
crypto.desc: Empties promises tough crypto, just like my gym membership! Break its signatures anyway!

crypto.name: Hartkit
crypto.desc: Hartkit stands guard, where massive, mismatched parameters create cryptographic chaos.

crypto.name: Laliga
crypto.desc:
To conquer Laliga demands mastery, so this codebased cipher tries to crushes weak algorithms.

Note: Due to an error in the Sage software, the correct output file was not generated, so the output_new.txt file was added to this challenge.

crypto.name: Maniab
crypto.desc: Beware Maniab’s twisted RSA, its bizarre parameters challenge conventional attacks.

crypto.name: Roosa Simple
crypto.desc:
Tiny primes guard Roosa! Break their deceptively simple cryptosystem to seize the flag.

Note: We decide to simplify the Roosa challenge, good luck!

pwn.name: ASISGX
pwn.desc: This is my high performance ASISGX web-server. RFCs? NAH i have a better idea ...

pwn.name: File No
pwn.desc:
Files can be numbered using this kernel module! Also download the vulnerable code!

Special thanks to the author, ptr-Yudai!

pwn.name: RandomJS
pwn.desc: Do you need a random element in JavaScript? I have the honor of presenting my proposal.

pwn.name: Ultimate Baby Bof
pwn.desc:
This is the ultimate babybof challenge.

Special thanks to the author, ptr-Yudai!

rev.name: Bludio
rev.desc: Try to decode the file captured from the terrorists to find the secret message in Bludio's proprietary software.

rev.name: Cycle of hatred
rev.desc: The real world is meaningful just with pain. This binary is trapped in a perpetual Cycle of Hatred. Reverse engineer its endless loop, find the flag, and finally break the cycle.

rev.name: Pain Is Justice
rev.desc: Pain is the ultimate form of justice, and this challenge is your trial. Endure the struggle, find the flag, and deliver your verdict.

rev.name: Serve The Mission
rev.desc: We stumbled upon an odd IoT artifact, noisy and restless like Stitch. Step in as Lilo, bring order to the mess, and Serve The Mission by finding the flag.

rev.name: Storm
rev.desc: Reverse the Storm binary to calm the crash and extract the hidden flag.

rev.name: Xelophene
rev.desc: Try your best to reverse engineer the Xelophene binary to extract the secret file from its core algorithm.

web.name: Pure leak
web.desc:
Just leak it!

Thanks to arkark as challenge author 🙏

web.name: SatoNote
web.desc:
I had an LLM write this code, so there shouldn't be any vulnerabilities... 👈🤖✍️​​​​​​💻... 🧠➡️🗑️... 🚫🐛⁉️

Can you outsmart the LLM and prove me wrong?

Note: Please obtain the flag locally before trying it on the production environment.

So find a the flag by exploring this service: http://65.109.184.196:8000

web.name: ScrapScrap I
web.desc:
A web service, http://91.107.176.228:3000, that allows users to scrape websites, but only offers demo accounts that check whether you can be scraped.

If you want to enjoy the service 100%, find a way to get a user account.

Thanks to Worty as author! 😊

web.name: ScrapScrap II
web.desc:
Having a user account is great in this service: http://91.107.176.228:4000, how about more?

Note: The attachment is changed! Please download it again!!

Thanks to Worty as author! 😊

web.name: ScrapScrap I Revenge
web.desc:
A Revenge web service, http://91.107.176.228:4000, that allows users to scrape websites, but only offers demo accounts that check whether you can be scraped.

If you want to enjoy the service 100%, find a way to get a user account.

"[22:11:12] => Worty: Oups i forgot to check that users are allowed to get the first flag.. i will patch it and sorry for that!"

Thanks to Worty as author! 😊

web.name: Under the Beamers
web.desc:
Clobbered or not clobbered, that's the question :)

See here: http://65.109.209.215:5000, the bot port is 4000!

Thanks to kevin-mizu as author! 😊

web.name: Under the Beamers Revenge
web.desc:
Clobbered or not clobbered, that's the question :)

web: http://65.109.209.215:15000/

bot: echo URL | http://65.109.209.215:14000/

Thanks to kevin-mizu as author! 😊
